transcript:
Therapist: You've made some great progress in identifying and challenging your negative core beliefs. Another helpful tool we can add to your coping card is a list of your personal strengths and positive qualities. This can serve as a reminder of your inherent worth, regardless of your job search outcomes. What are some strengths you recognize in yourself?

Patient: Well, I know I'm persistent. Even when things get tough, I don't give up easily. And I'm pretty creative when it comes to problem-solving.

Therapist: Those are excellent strengths. Persistence and creativity are valuable assets in any career, and in life in general. I'd also add that you have a lot of insight and self-awareness. You've been able to identify patterns in your thinking and challenge them, which shows a high level of emotional intelligence.

Patient: I never really thought of it that way, but I guess you're right. It's just hard to focus on the positive when I'm feeling down about the job search.

Therapist: That's understandable. When we're stressed or depressed, it's easy to get tunnel vision and only see the negative. That's why having a physical reminder, like your coping card, can be so helpful. It can snap you out of that negative spiral and bring your attention back to your strengths and capabilities.

Patient: That makes sense. I'll add those to my card.

Therapist: Great. Another thing to include might be some of your accomplishments, both big and small. Completing your degree is a significant one, but there may be others that are meaningful to you personally.

Patient: I did win an award for a project I worked on during my undergrad. And I've had a few photography pieces published in local magazines.

Therapist: Those are wonderful accomplishments! They demonstrate your talent, hard work, and ability to produce high-quality results. Definitely add those to your card as well.

Patient: Okay, I will.

Therapist: As you continue to add to your coping card, remember that it's a living document. You can keep adding to it as you make progress and achieve new milestones. It's a way of tracking your growth and celebrating your successes, no matter how small they may seem.

Patient: I like that idea. It's like a portable portfolio of my strengths and achievements.

Therapist: Exactly! And the more you engage with it, the more those positive aspects of yourself will be reinforced in your mind. It's a way of rewiring your brain to focus on your strengths rather than your perceived shortcomings.

Patient: That's a nice thought. I'm looking forward to seeing how it evolves over time.

Therapist: That's a great attitude to have. Remember, your coping card is a tool for growth, not a static document. As you continue to challenge your negative beliefs and build on your strengths, it will grow and change along with you.

Patient: It's kind of exciting to think about, actually.

Therapist: That sense of excitement is a good sign. It means you're open to the process of growth and self-discovery. And that openness will serve you well as you continue on your journey.

Patient: I'm ready to see where it takes me.

Therapist: That's wonderful to hear. Remember, your journey is unique to you, and it's not about reaching some perfect end point. It's about engaging with the process and learning from each experience along the way.

Patient: That's a nice perspective. It takes some of the pressure off.

Therapist: Absolutely. Growth is not a straight line, and there will be ups and downs. But each experience, whether positive or challenging, is an opportunity to learn and evolve. And your coping card will be there to support you through it all.

Patient: It's nice to know I have that support, even if it's just a small card.

Therapist: Don't underestimate the power of that small card! It represents your resilience, your strengths, and your commitment to your own well-being. And those are powerful things indeed.

Patient: When you put it that way, it does feel pretty significant.

Therapist: It is significant, Jian. And it's a testament to the progress you've made and the work you've put in. Your coping card is a symbol of your growth and your capacity for resilience in the face of challenges.

Patient: It's a nice reminder to have, for sure.

Therapist: Hold onto that reminder, and engage with it regularly. The more you do, the more those positive aspects of yourself will be reinforced, and the more naturally you'll be able to access them when you need them most.

Patient: I'll definitely keep that in mind.

Therapist: Remember, your coping card is just one tool in your growing toolbox of coping strategies. As we continue our work together, we'll keep adding to that toolbox, building on your strengths and developing new skills to support your growth and well-being.

Patient: It's nice to know I have options, and that I'm not just stuck with the negative thoughts.

Therapist: You absolutely have options, and you're not stuck with anything. You have the power to change your relationship with your thoughts, and to cultivate a more balanced and compassionate perspective towards yourself.

Patient: It's a new way of thinking, but I like it.

Therapist: Embracing new ways of thinking is a key part of the process. It allows you to expand your perspective and discover new possibilities for growth and self-discovery.

Patient: I'm looking forward to seeing where it leads me.

Therapist: That sense of openness and curiosity will serve you well on this journey. Remember, each step you take, no matter how small, is a step towards greater self-understanding and resilience.

Patient: It's a nice thought to hold onto.

Therapist: Hold onto that thought, and let it guide you as you continue to engage with the process. Trust that each experience, each insight, is a valuable part of your journey, and that you have the strength and the tools to navigate whatever challenges may arise.

Patient: It's a comforting thought, for sure.

Therapist: Let that thought be a source of comfort and motivation as you continue on your path. Remember, you're not alone in this journey. You have your coping card, your toolbox of skills, and our work together to support you along the way.

Patient: It's nice to know I have that support.

Therapist: You absolutely do. And that support will continue to grow and evolve, just as you will. Trust in the process, and in your own capacity for growth and resilience.

Patient: I will. It's a nice feeling, knowing I have that to rely on.

Therapist: Hold onto that feeling, and let it be a source of strength and comfort as you continue on your journey. Remember, each step you take is a step towards greater self-understanding and well-being, and you have the tools and the support to navigate whatever challenges may arise.

Patient: It's a nice thought to hold onto, for sure.

Therapist: Let that thought be a guiding light as you continue to engage with the process. Trust that each experience, each insight, is a valuable part of your journey, and that you have the strength and the resources to navigate whatever challenges may arise.

Patient: I'm looking forward to seeing where it leads me.

Therapist: That sense of openness and curiosity will serve you well on this journey. Remember, each step you take, no matter how small, is a step towards greater self-understanding and resilience.
